intro: Malvastrum hirtipes, commonly known as the woolly mallow, is a flowering plant native to the southwestern United States and northern Mexico. It is characterized by its fuzzy, hairy stems and leaves, which give it a distinctive, soft appearance. The plant produces showy, pink to purple flowers that bloom in summer, attracting pollinators such as bees and butterflies. It thrives in well-drained soils and full sun, making it a hardy perennial in arid and semi-arid environments. Its botanical features make it a popular choice for xeriscaping and native plant gardens.
